choices.text: Melanoma
Basal cell carcinoma
Squamous cell carcinoma
Bartholin gland adenocarcinoma

questions.text: A 72y old woman who preseted with a lesion on the vulva underwent a biopsy. This was diagnosed as squamois cell carcinoma which is the most common pathology in vulvar cancers. Which of the following is the second most common vulvar malignancy and accounts for up to 10 percent of all vulvar cancers?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Melanoma

Explanation

  • Of vulvar tumors, approximately 90 percent are squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Malignant melanoma is the second most common, but rare histologic subtypes may also be encountered.

Educational Objective:

  • The etiology of vulval cancer is unclear but certain high risk factors are known to be associated
    • Postmenopausal women; median age about 60 years
    • White race
    • Obesity, Hypertension and Diabetes are known associations
    • More common in nulliparous women
    • Lichen sclerosis
    • HPV (esp high risk types - 16,18)
    • Chronic vulvar irritation
    • Premalignant lesions - vulvar intra-epithelial neoplasia

Ref: Page 707, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Lichen planus
Tobacco abuse
Lichen sclerosus
Human papillomavirus

questions.text: A 65y postmenopausal woman is dignosed with vulval cancer. She is very surprised as she has been having a very healthy lifestyle. She asks you the risk factors for vulval cancer. Which of the following is not a risk factor for vulval cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans: A Lichen planus

Explanation

Risk factors of vulvar cancer are

  • More common in older age (> 60y) and white race
  • Increased association with obesity, HTN, diabetes and nulliparoty
  • Associated vulvar epithelial disorders: Lichensclerosis, Vulval intra-epithelial neoplasia (VIN), Paget's disease, squamous cell hyperplasia, condyloma acuminata
  • HPV (high risk type 16, 18)
  • Chronic pruritis, chronic irritation of the vulva
  • Vulvar intra-epithepithelial lesion (VIN)

 

Lichen planus may affect the skin anywhere on the body. It affects the mucosal surfaces (oral mucosa) and presents with polygenal flat-topped purpuric plaques. The lesion may be erosive and presents more with pain than pruritus. It is NOT commonly associated with vulvar carcinoma

Educational Objective:

 

Risk factors of vulvar cancer are

  • More common in older age (> 60y) and white race
  • Increased association with obesity, HTN, diabetes and nulliparoty
  • Associated vulvar epithelial disorders: Lichensclerosis, Vulval intra-epithelial neoplasia (VIN), Paget's disease, squamous cell hyperplasia, condyloma acuminata
  • HPV (high risk type 16, 18)
  • Chronic pruritis, chronic irritation of the vulva
  • Vulvar intra-epithepithelial lesion (VIN)

Ref: Page no 708, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Biopsy the lesion in your office
Prescribe estrogen cream and follow up in 3 months
Perform a wide local excision in the operating room
Prescribe clobetasol

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents for her annual well woman examination and complains of vulvar pruritis. During examination, you note an area of thickened white plaque. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Biopsy the lesion in your office

Explanation:

  • A post-menopausal woman with a vulvar lesion should be biopsied to rule out vulvar malignancy. 
  • Lesions may be raised, ulcerated, pigmented, or warty
  • Importantly, other clinical entities may present similarly and include preinvasive neoplasia (VIN), infection, chronic inflammatory disease, and granulomatous disease, so a biopsy should be done. 
  • Multiple biopsies are recommended, from the most suspicious raised or dyspigmented skin are taken
  • Concurrent colposcopic examination of the cervix and vagina and careful evaluation of the perianal area are recommended to diagnose any synchronous lesions or associated neoplasm of the lower genital tract

Other options

  • Clobetasol is a local steroid which may help in several skin conditions but a biopsy is important before prescribing medication
  • Estrogen cream is prescribed for vaginal/ vulvar dryness/ dyspareunia in post menopausal women (Hormone replacement therapy). However the above image does not appear to be a menopausal related vulvar lesion
  • Once biopsy shows a vulvar malignancy, then further evaluation is done to stage the tumor (clinical staging). For microscopic lesions, a wide local excision can be done

Educational Objective: 

  • A post-menopausal woman with a vulvar lesion should be biopsied to rule out vulvar malignancy. 
  • Lesions may be raised, ulcerated, pigmented, or warty
  • Importantly, other clinical entities may present similarly and include preinvasive neoplasia (VIN), infection, chronic inflammatory disease, and granulomatous disease, so a biopsy should be done. 
  • Multiple biopsies are recommended, from the most suspicious raised or dyspigmented skin are taken
  • Concurrent colposcopic examination of the cervix and vagina and careful evaluation of the perianal area are recommended to diagnose any synchronous lesions or associated neoplasm of the lower genital tract

Ref: Page no 708, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Grade
Tumor size
Depth of invasion
Lymph node metastasis

questions.text: A 56y woman is diagnosed to have a stage 2 vulvar carcinoma and she undergoes a radical vulvectomy. What is the most important prognostic factor in vulvar cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Lymph node metastasis

Explanation

Prognostic factors in vulval ca are:

  1. Lymph node metastases (This is the single most important vulvar cancer predictor, since inguinal node metastasis reduces long-term survival rates by 50 percent)
  2. FIGO Stage
  3. Lesion size
  4. Depth of invasion
  5. Resected-margin status and
  6. Lymphatic vascular space involvement (LVSI)

 

 

Ref: Page 710, Williams Gyn, 3rd edition

choices.text: Spare the saphenous vein
Use compression stockings
Transpose the sartorius muscle
Avoid drain placement at the time of inguinofemoral dissection

questions.text: What technique can decrease the risk of lymphedema in inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy ?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spare the saphenous vein.

 

Explanation

 

  • Chronic lymphedema is a well-known complication following inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy, particularly in the management of vulvar cancer.
  • Preservation o the saphenous vein has been shown to reduce the incidence
  • Regardless, this condition is typically much more problematic with the addition of groin radiation
  • Supportive management is meant to minimize the edema and prevent symptomatic progression.
  • Foot elevation, compression stockings, and, on occasion, diuretic therapy may be helpful

 

 

Ref: !245, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: It is typically a disease of the elderly
It commonly arises from the labia minora and clitoris
Differential diagnoses include seborrheic keratosis and dysplastic nevi
It is more common in African American women than Caucasian women

questions.text: Which of the following is INCORRECT regarding the tumor shown here involving the outer surface of the right labia minora?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. It is more common in African American women than Caucasian women.

Explanation:

  • This is a vulvar carcinoma which appears like a melanoma as It is pigmented
  • Let us discuss all the options: 
    • Option A: It is typically a disease of the elderly: This is correct. Vulvla melanoma disproprtionately affects the elderly 
    • Option B: It commonly arises from the labia minora and clitoris. This is also correct. The common sites are the laboa minora, majora and clitoris
    • Option C: Differential diagnoses include seborrheic keratosis and dysplastic nevi. This is also correct. Diferential diagnosis include pigmented lesions like include lentigo simplex, vulvar melanosis, acanthosis nigricans, seborrheic keratosis, and nevi
    • Option D. It is more common in African American women than Caucasian women: This is incorrect. It is more common amongst whites. 

Educational Objective:

  • Vulval melanoma is the second most common vulvar cancer and accounts or 10 percent of all vulvar malignancies.
  • Vulvar melanoma disproportionately affects the elderly and develops more commonly among whites than other races.
  • Vulvar melanoma has an overall poor prognosis, and 5-year survival rates range from 8 to 55 percent
  • Malignant vulvar melanomas most commonly arise from the labia minora, labia majora, or clitoris
  • Some benign pigmented lesions can also be found here and include lentigo simplex, vulvar melanosis, acanthosis nigricans, seborrheic keratosis, and nevi
  • Tissue sampling is mandatory for diagnosis

 

Ref: Page 716, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

3 mm
5 mm
7 mm

questions.solution:
Ans: A. 1 mm

Minimally invasive vulvar cancer is Stage 1a1 where the depth of invasion is < 1mm

Educational Objective:

Ref: Page no 682, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: Ultrasonography
CT scan
MRI
All of the above

questions.text: A 55 years old P5L5 presented to OPD with postcoital bleeding and vaginal discharge. On examination, there is a 3 x 3cm growth involving the entire cervix. The growth does not seem to extend to the vagina and the parametrium is free. Which of the following investigations can be used for staging of cancer cervix:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

In 2018, the FIGO (Federation of International Gynecologists and Obstetricians) Gynecologic Oncology Committee revised the staging to allow the option of clinical, radiological, or pathological findings, as available, to assign the stage. FIGO 2018 staging permits the use of any of the imaging modalities according to available resources, i.e. ultrasound, computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), positron emission tomography (PET), to provide additional information on tumor size, nodal status, and local or systemic spread.

 

MRI is the best method of radiologic assessment of primary tumors greater than 10 mm.

 

The stage is allocated after all imaging and pathology reports are available. It is not to be altered later, for example at recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cervical cancer is primarily a clinical staging but FIGO 2018 staging permits the use of any of the imaging modalities according to available resources, i.e. ultrasound, computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), positron emission tomography (PET), to provide additional information on tumor size, nodal status, and local or systemic spread.

 

Ref  : FIGO cancer report 2021

choices.text: Stage IB1
Stage IB2
Stage IB3
Stage IIA1

questions.text: A 57 year old woman presents to OPD with complaint of discharge per vagina. There is a 3*3 cm visible growth on the cervix. Vagina and parametrium are uninvolved. The stage of the disease is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Stage IB2

  • In this patient, the cancer is limited to the cervix and between 2 cm to 4 cm so this is 1B2

Educational Objective:

Staging of cervical cancr is essential to learn as given in the table above

Ref :  FIGO cancer report 2021

choices.text: Stage IIA1
Stage IIA2
Stage IIBr
Stage IIIB2r

questions.text: A 50 years lady presents with foul smelling vaginal discharge since a few months. She is post-menopausal since 2 years. On examination, there is a 3.5 x 3cm growth, involving the upper part of vagina and bilateral parametrium appears free. An MRI done, shows growth involving upper vagina and parametrium, but not upto the lateral pelvic wall. The stage of the disease is:
questions.solution:
Ans: C: Stage IIBr

 

FIGO CANCER REPORT 2021

Staging of cancer cervix: 

  • Cervical cancer is a clinical staging but certain investigations and pathology can be used to aid in staging. 
  • As per the recent FIGO staging (20021), this is Stage II B r
  • 'r' refers to findings on 'radiology'

Staging of Cervical cancer (FIGO 2021)

 

Educational Objectve: 

Cervical cancer staging is primarily a clinical staging and it it svery important to know the staging as shown in the table above

Ref: Berek and novak 16th edition, 2455

choices.text: II
III
IVA

questions.text: A gynecological oncologist performs a radical vulvectomy and bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection for a 3-cm invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva involving the lower third of the vagina. The final histo-pathologic analysis of the specimen reveals margins and lymph nodes that are negative for cancer. Based on these findings, which International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) stage is she assigned?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. II

As per the FIGO staging, the patient is Stage II

choices.text: Chemoradiation
Pelvic exenteration
Chemoradiation followed by radical vulvectomy
Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a 55-yearold patient with a 4-cm squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva involving the urethral meatus and a medical history significant for systemic lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection

Explanation

  • This patient is stage 3 vulvar cancer. 
  • The management of stage 3 vulcar cancer is modified radical vulvectomy with b/l inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy

Educational Objective: 

Treatment of vulval cancer

  • For both stage I and stage 2 disease: radical local excision and sentinel node dissection is indicated, and groin dissection is reserved for those with metastasis to the sentinel node(s).
  • For stage 3:
    • Modified radical or radical vulvectomy with inguinal and femoral lymphadenectomy is the standard therapy.
    • Nodal involvement is a key determinant of survival. Radiation therapy is given to patients with large primary lesions and narrow margins.
  • Stage 4:
    • Radical vulvectomy and pelvic exenteration may be indicated for patients with stage IVA vulvar cancer.
    • Surgery followed by radiation therapy may be done for large, resected lesions with narrow margins.
  • This patient has a stage 2 or 3 vulvar carcinoma (As lymph nodal status is not mentioned); and the best treatment option is a radical vulvectomy with b/l LN inguino-femoral dissection
  • Her medical history wil not change her treatment

 

Ref: Page no 714, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin
Wide local excision with a 2-cm margin
Radical vulvectomy with right inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a 3-cm basal cell carcinoma of the right vulva, 2cm from the midline?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin

Explanation

  • This is a basal cell carcinoma
  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) of the vulva accounts or < 2 percent of all vulvar cancers and is most commonly found in elderly women
  • Lesions typically arise on the labia majora, are characterized by poor pigmentation and pruritus, and often mimic eczema, psoriasis, or intertrigo. .
  • Basal cell carcinoma is removed by radical partial vulvectomy using a minimum surgical margin of 1 cm.
  • Lymphatic or distant spread is rare, but inguino femoral lymphadenectomy or Sentniel lymoh node biopsy is considered on clinically suspicious nodes.

 

 

Ref: Page 717, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Barrier methods
Copper T
Injection DMPA
Oral contraceptive pills

questions.text: You are counselling a patient regarding management of molar pregnancy. Which of the following contraceptive is contraindicated in patients after evacuation for molar pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Copper T

  • Patients are encouraged to use effective contraception during the entire interval of hCG follow-up.
  • Because of the potential risk of uterine perforation, bleeding, and infection, intrauterine devices should not be inserted until the patient achieves a normal hCG level.
  • If the patient does not desire surgical sterilization, either oral contraceptives or barrier methods should be used.

Other Options

  • Option A: Barrier contraception: Barrier method of contraception is safe and can be used
  • Option C: Inj DMPA:  Injection DMPA can be used safely
  • Option D: Combined oral contraceptive pills: Combined oral pills can be used after the hCG value has become normal

Educational Objective: 

  • Post molar evacuation, contraception is advised till the period of beta hCG surveillance
  • All contraceptives are safe except Intra-Uterine Devices. 
  • Combined OCPs can be started after beta hCG values return to normal

Ref: berek and novak, 16th edition, page 2772

choices.text: Choriocarcinoma
Epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (ETT)
Molar pregnancy
Placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT)

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia includes all Except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Molar pregnancy

       Modified WHO Classification of GTD

Gestational Trophoblastic  Neoplasias include the following: 

  • Invasive mole
  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Placental site trophoblatic tumor
  • Epitheloid trophoblastic tumor

Molar pregnancy (partial anc complete) aren't included under gestational trophoblastic neoplasias. 

Educational Objective: 

Gestational Trophoblastic  Neoplasias include the following: 

  • Invasive mole
  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Placental site trophoblatic tumor
  • Epitheloid trophoblastic tumor

 

 

Ref: FIGO cancer report 2021

choices.text: Stage 1
Stage 2
Stage 3
Stage 4

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has been admitted after 3 increasing weekly hCG values, 2 months after molar evacuation. On examination, cervix, vagina is healthy, uterus is normal size. Her Hb is 10g%, chest X-ray is shown below. What stage of GTN does she have?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Stage 3

TABLE 1. FIGO staging and classification for gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) is as shown in the table

  • As the patient in the given scenario has typical canon ball lung metastases on the chest X-Ray, she is Stage 3. 
  • Also note that lung metastases in GTN signifies a good prognosis and is very responsive to single agent chemotherapy with MEthotrexate being the drug of choice. 

Educational Objective: 

Staging of GTN: 

Ref: FIGO cancer report 2021, Berek & novak, 16th ed page 2775

choices.text: Actinomycin D injection 5-day regimen
EMA-CO regimen
Methotrexate-folinic acid 8-day regimen
Hysterectomy

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman develops GTN  10 months after abortion. Her beta hCG value is 1,20,000 mIU/mL. The chest X ray shows metastasis. The appropriate treatment for her would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. EMA-CO regimen

  • From the information we have, her WHO prognostic score (See table below) would be:
    • Age: 22: Scor 0
    • Previous pregnancy: Abortion: Score: 1
    • Interval from index pregnancy: 8 months: Score: 2
    • hCG level: 120000: Score: 4
    • Lung mets: Score 0
    • Size of tumor: Not mentioned
    • No of mets: Not mentiones
    • Previous chemotherapy: not mentioned
  • Total score = 7 which is HIGH RISK (Score > 6 is high risk)
  • High risk requires multi agent chemotherapy with EMACO 

    

World Health Organization scoring system based on prognostic factors modified as FIGO score

 

  • A risk score of 6 and below is classified as low risk and above 6 is considered high risk.
  • EMA-CO (etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, vincristine) chemotherapy

 

 

 

 

Other Options

  • Option A: Actinomycin D injection 5-day regimen: Actinomycin D is not the drug of choice in GTN. Methotrexate is the drug of choice in low risk GTN
  • Option C: Methotrexate folinic acid 8 day regime: This is the preferred drug in low risk GTN. This patient has high risk GTN as her score is 7. 
  • Option D:  Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is rarely done in GTN. Indications include excessive bleeding or uterine perforation. Rarely in chemoresistance, hysterectomy can be resorted to. 

Educational Objective: 

  • The WHO prognostic scoring system in GTN determines the type of chemotherapy
  • If the score is ≤ 6, the patient requires single agent (Methotrexate) chemotherpay. This is given as 4 doses (1mg/Kg) alternating with 4 doses of folinic acid (0.1mg/kg) every 2-3 weeks. 
  • If the score > 7 the patient requires multiagent chemotherapy (EMACO). This includes etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, vincristine

Ref: FIGO cancer report 2021

choices.text: EMA-CO regimen
Embolisation of vaginal nodule
Methotrexate-folinic acid 8 day regimen
Hysterectomy

questions.text: A 22-year woman develops GTN, 6 months after molar evacuation. On speculum examination, there is a reddish blue nodule in vagina. Her hCG is 24,000mIU/mL. chest XRay is normal. Mhe most appropriate treatment for her is
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Methotrexate-folinic acid 8 day regimen

  • As per the WHO prognostic scoring for GTN (shown in the table below, her score is 3
    • Age 22:0
    • Post molar evacuation:  0
    • Interval: 6 months: 1
    • hCG 24000: 1
    • Mets: 1
    • Site of mets: vagina: 0
    • Prev chemo: 0
    • Size not provided
  • Therefore single agent multidose chemotherapy (Methotrexate with folinic acd) is preferred 

  • A risk score of 6 and below is classified as low risk and above 6 is considered high risk.
  • First-line single agent chemotherapy regimens for low-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia include methorexate (alternating with folinic acid). 2nd line drug is Actinomycin D. 

Other Options: 

Option A: EMA-CO: This is the regime of choice in high risk GTN (Score of 7 and above)

Option B: Embolization of vaginal nodule: Vaginal metastases may bleed profusely and torrential bleeding can occur following biopsy of a lesion. To control the bleeding, plication, packing the vagina or performing a wide local excision. Angiographic embolization of the hypogastric arteries can also be done. 

Option D: Hysterectomy is not an option in vaginal metastases in GTN

Ref: FIGO Cancer Report 2021

choices.text: 2 weekly chemotherapy, response monitored by CA 125
4 weekly chemotherapy, response monitored by CA 125
2 weekly chemotherapy, response monitored by hCG
4 weekly chemotherapy, response monitored by hCG

questions.text: A 30-year woman with stage 2 GTN is receiving methotrexate-based chemotherapy. How frequently is chemotherapy given and what marker is used to assess response to treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2 weekly chemotherapy, response monitored by Hcg

  • hCG is used as a marker to diagnose development of GTN, response to chemotherapy and occurance of relapse
  • Both EMACO and Methotrexate are given 2 weekly

Other Options

  • Option A and B: Monitoring is not by Ca 125. Ca 125 is a marker for epithelial ovarrianc ancer but is also found to be raised in fibroid, endometriosis, pregnancy, PID and genital TB
  • Option D: Methotrexate is given 2 weekly as per the recent FIGO cancer report of 2021. 

Educational Objective: 

  • hCG is used as a marker to diagnose development of GTN, response to chemotherapy and occurance of relapse
  • Both EMACO and Methotrexate are given 2 weekly
  • EMACO is given for high risk GTN
  • Methotrexate is given for low risk GTN

Ref: FIGO cancer report 2021, Berek and Novak 16th ed Page 2757

choices.text: Chemotherapy is given for one cycle followed by hCG follow up
Chemotherapy is given for 6 cycles followed by hCG follow up
Chemotherapy is given till hCG undetectable followed by hCG follow up
Chemotherapy is given till hCG undetectable followed by 2-3 consolidation cycles followed by hCG follow up

questions.text: Regarding chemotherapy in GTN, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Chemotherapy is given till hCG undetectable followed by 2-3 consolidation cycles followed by hCG follow up

  • Administration of single-agent chemotherapy (generally 8-day MTX-FA for low risk GTN) every 2 weeks until hCG is undetected and then three consolidation courses to reduce the risk of relapse is recommended
  • Patients who require combination chemotherapy (EMACO for high risk GTN) must be treated intensively to attain remission. Combination chemotherapy should be given as often as toxicity permits until the patient achieves three consecutive normal hCG levels. After normal hCG levels are attained, at least three additional courses of chemotherapy are administered to reduce the risk of relapse.

Educational Objective: 

  • Chemotherapy for GTN (for low risk: Mtx-FA and high risk: EMA-CO), it is given 2 weekly till hCG levels are undetectable followed by 2-3 consolidation doses 

 

Ref: berek & novak 16 edition, page 2785, 2786

choices.text: 0
5
30
50

questions.text: What percentage of vulvar cancers is positive for human papillomavirus (HPV)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 50

Explanation

Risk factors of vulvar cancer are

  • More common in older age (> 60y) and white race
  • Increased association with obesity, HTN, diabetes and nulliparoty
  • Associated vulvar epithelial disorders: Lichensclerosis, Vulval intra-epithelial neoplasia (VIN), Paget's disease, squamous cell hyperplasia, condyloma acuminata
  • HPV (high risk type 16, 18): in 50% of cases. A history of HPV genital warts have a 35-fold increased risk for developing vulvar cancer compared with women who have never developed these lesions. 
  • Chronic pruritis, chronic irritation of the vulva
  • Vulvar intra-epithepithelial lesion (VIN)

Educational Objective:

HPV (high risk type 16, 18): is seen in 50% of cases of vulvar cancer.  A history of HPV genital warts have a 35-fold increased risk for developing vulvar cancer compared with women who have never developed these lesions.

Ref: Page no 708, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Lymphocele
Lymphedema
Groin infection
Wound dehiscence

questions.text: A 64y lady undergoes radical vulvectomy with inguinofermoral lymoh node dissection for vulvar cancer. What is the most common complication of an inguinofemoral lymph node dissection?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Lymphedema

Explanation

Following inguino-femoral lymph node dissection, the following complications are noted: 

  1. Lymphedema: Amongst all complications, the most common complication of inguino-femoral LN dissection is a lymohedema
  2. Lymphocele
  3. Groin infection
  4. Groin necrosis
  5. Groin seperation

Ref: Page no 715, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: Radiation alone
Chemoradiation
Close observation
Pelvic lymph node dissection

questions.text: You perform a radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy on a woman with a 4-cm squamous cell carcinoma tumor of the vulva. Margins are negative for cancer, but there are three positive lymph nodes. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Chemoradiation

Explanation

  • This is a stage III vulvar cancers (Tumor of any size with or without extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethera, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with positive inguino-femoral nodes. 
  • Women with stage III vulvar cancer are treated with surger followed by adjuvant radiation therapy directed to both groins and the pelvis.
  • The addition of platinum-based chemotherapy concurrent with radiation therapy is also now given, and hence the best answer here is chemo-radiation

 

Ref: Page 714, Williams Gyn, 3rd edition

choices.text: Antibiotics
Incision and drainage with marsupialization
Incision and drainage with excision of the gland
Incision and drainage

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with the persistent vulvar mass seen in the picture below and complaints of dyspareunia.  What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Incision and drainage with excision of the gland

Explanation

  • This is a Bartholin gland cyst
  • Bartholin gland enlargement in a woman older than 40 years and recurrent cysts or abscesses warrants a biopsy or excision as there could be an underlying adenocarcinoma
  • In a young woman, the treatment of choice of a Bartholin duct cyst is marsupialiation

 

Ref: Page no 718, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: SLNB is usually not recommended in vulvar carcinoma as lymphatic spread is rare
SLNB is primarily used for staging and does not influence the management of vulvar carcinoma
SLNB is used to identify the 1st lymph node(s) that cancer cells are likely to spread to and can guide lymph node dissection if positive
SLNB is the sole definitive treatment for vulvar carcinoma and eliminates the need for further surgery or radiotherapy

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a suspicious vulvar lesion. A biopsy confirms the presence of squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. Clinical exam and imaging show no evidence of metastases. Her healthcare team decided to perform a sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) to assess lymph node involvement. Which of the following is a true statement?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. SLNB is used to identify the 1st lymph node(s) that cancer cells are likely to spread to and can guide lymph node dissection if positive

 

Explanation

 

Role of Sentinel LN Biopsy in Vulvar Carcinoma

  • Reduces the requirement of LN dissection in vulvar carcinoma
  • The main route of spread of vulvar carcinoma is lymphatic spread
  • Done by lymphoscintigraphy with Tc99 labelled isosulfan blue dye/ indocyanine fluorescent green
  • Groin incision made 10 mins later
  • Colored node is excised and examined
  • If negative: No lymphadenectomy needs to be done
  • If positive: B/l inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy is done

Other Options:

  • Option A. SLNB is usually not recommended in vulvar carcinoma as lymphatic spread is rare: This is a wrong statement as lymphatic spread is the most common route of spread of vulvar cancers
  • Option B. SLNB is primarily used for staging and does not influence the management of vulvar carcinoma: This is a wrong statement as SLNB is mainly done to reduce the risk of LN dissection thereby preventing complications
  • Option D: SLNB is the sole definitive treatment for vulvar carcinoma and eliminates the need for further surgery or radiotherapy: This is a wrong statement as SLNB is not the mainstay of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Role of Sentinel LN Biopsy in Vulvar Carcinoma

  • Reduces the requirement of LN dissection in vulvar carcinoma
  • The main route of spread of vulvar carcinoma is lymphatic spread

 

 

Ref: page 686, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition
